content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												I really like this game, and the graphics and sound design are pretty good for a budget game; the environments are especially creepy and the use of glow sticks and flares is fun too.  This game’s main downside is that it suffered an increasingly popular gameplay mechanic that indie developers (mostly) utilize in budget ($15-$20 on Steam) horror games – that of the random and/or pointless ‘fetch’ quest.  In Daylight’s case this takes the form of finding scraps of paper with a glowing sigil on them.   Once you find enough, some key-like item can then be collected from a magically-bound room that you in turn must use on a magically barred room/passage to proceed on to the next location, etc. Of course you have to backtrack to find said ‘barred’ room/passage which can be a real pain in the a$$ considering that you can’t use a flare at that point to ward off the witches (the ghosts that appear in the game) and the map on the phone your character continually holds out (light is always on at least) in her right hand isn’t very helpful.  One other factor some will have an issue with is length - Daylight will only take most peeps on Steam about 1.5 – 2 hrs to complete.  Granted, that is a pretty short length for a game, but when considering that the basis of this game is the proverbial ‘fetch’ quest, that doesn’t seem so bad in retrospect (seriously, would anyone want to endure a game that is 10+ hrs, or perhaps far longer, when that was the sole basis of said game? I think not!). There are trading cards, achievements and controller support as well, so that makes playing more enjoying and the achievements at least add some replay value if that’s your thing.Not a bad game to finish on per se (the developers closed up shop after 20+ yrs recently so hopefully you won’t suffer a bug that prevents you from playing this game properly, if at all, as you just may be SOL at that point) and with the drop from $15 to $10 it definitely wouldn’t hurt to look into grabbing a copy for yourself.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Okay. This game started out interesting and scary. It is extremely similar to Slender in that you have to collect multiple pages, referred to as remnants, to advance to the next level. The more pages you collect the higher the "threat" level. I won't give too much away, but as you progress further into the game it becomes much less scary and more of a hassle. The story line is interesting but hard to follow as none of the articles collected are put into a coherent or chronological order. The ending was extremely dissappointing and, as much as I hate to use this as a descriptive term, stupid and quick. The game is overall, confusing with no real explanation as to why the character is in this place. It leaves many questions unanswered and has an extremely predictable and cliche ending. The game hits the "climax" if it can so be called, and quickly ends with barely a falling action and no resolution. The graphics were very well done and it looked very beautiful. If you want a game that is good with jump scares for a little while and good looking, then look no further. Each level has a randomly generated map, presenting with a unique experience with each play, but, overall, it is wasted on the poor plotline. (Last line of review credited to my boyfriend who watched me play this and chimed in as I reviewed.)Fun 2/5, Scary 3/5, Graphics 4/5, Plot 1/5, Worth the Price? For graphics yes, for plot and gameplay no. Buy on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Have you ever hated a game?Have you ever hated a game so much that you keep beating your head against it, like it's a brick wall and you're not going to stop until you get a concussion?Daylight is that game for me. Zombie Studios is notorious for producing sub-par products - and Daylight is no exception to that rule: the challenges that it present are laughable at best (in the case of the intended challenge of the witches, which can be avoided by staring at the floor like a shoegaze guitarist and - well, shoe gazing); and absurd at worst (in the case of achievement hunting, which is a chore). Like the gameplay, the story is clunky and poorly delivered. There is a cyclical system to witchery in this world, that begins with the death of witches, and follows a twelve-step program to awaken the power within the witches' descendent.The one thing that's charming about the game is the narrator - a spooky doctor who's doing his very best to monologue like Anthony Hopkin's Lecter. His overacting is a source of unexpected levity in an otherwise tedious experience.That aside, don't make the same mistake I did. I'm going to finish the long quest of achievement hunting and then uninstall for good.
